newsitem.title: USA: U.S. stocks seen taking cue from oil outlook, data.
newsitem.headline: U.S. stocks seen taking cue from oil outlook, data.

text.p: U.S. stocks were in for a directionless open on Wednesday, as Wall Street awaits a key jobs report due Friday and more information on the future of oil prices.
Construction data, due at 1000 EDT/1400 GMT, could also move stocks and bonds.

"A follow through of yesterday's gains is really a matter of question," said Alan Ackerman, market strategist at Fahnestock and Co. "The new element in the economic story is the prospect of rising oil prices."
Ackerman said stocks would also be battling worries about interest rates, historical weakness during the month of September, and a lack of conviction ahead of the jobs data.
"Should they be strong, its likely to prompt a selloff," he said. U.S. August payroll and unemployment numbers are due Friday.

This morning's July construction spending figures are expected to fall 0.2 percent compared to a June gain of 1.2 percent. At 0900 EDT/1300 GMT, BTM Schroders releases chain store sales for the week ended August 31 compared to the prior week.

"I suspect were in for some profit taking at the open, which will hurt the Dow initially, and then another gyration day for stocks," said Peter Cardillo, director of research at Westfalia Investments.
"The market is going to take a very cautious attitude before the report due Friday. We could see a 20 point range from low to high and maybe some profit taking in oil stocks," Cardillo said.
"But if construction data is softer than expected or on target, the market could follow yesterday's pattern, when it overcame early losses to close up 32 points," he said.
"The real key to the Iraq situation was the fact that the Iraqi oil deal was suspended. That's what hit oil prices and stocks," Cardillo said.
The long bond was off 8/32 to yield 7.08 percent.
Tokyo stocks closed slightly higher, mostly brushing off news of the second U.S. missile attack on Iraq, with the Nikkei 225 index up 4 to 20202.
U.S. shares were narrowly mixed in light and featureless trading in London with U.S. oil companies mostly flat ahead of the market open in the United States.
The dollar fell slightly against the yen, hovering below the 109 mark in European trading.
Standard & Poor's Futures were off 0.60 to 655.25, indicating a slightly lower opening.
McDonald's shares slipped slightly in London trading after the Wall Street Journal's "Heard on the Street" column said the company's new Arch Deluxe burger was not boosting sales.
Stratton Oakmont is still trying to find a public market for E-Net, according to the "Marketplace" column of the New York Times.
